moves.1. e4: 1.e4  is the most common first move for white
moves.1... e5 2. Nf3: This move develops a piece and at the same time threatens the e5 pawn.
moves.2... Nc6: Black develops a piece and at the same time supports the e5 pawn
moves.3. Bc4 Bc5 4. b4:
This move initiates the Evans Gambit. The Evans Gambit happens to be 
  another old-time favorite. White sacrifices a pawn so that he can gain time by
  pushing Black's Bishop around. Players these days prefer 4. d3 for a much 
  quieter game.
moves.5. c3:
The point of this move is to  
   1. Attack Black's Bishop
   2. Getting ready to play 6.d4 ( which was played in the game)
   3. Allowing the Queen access to the Q-side when it will go to b3 set up a 
       battery on the a2-g8 diagonal and attack Black's weakness ( the f7 pawn)
moves.6. d4:
Another pawn sacrifice.  White blows apart the center in the hope that the 
   new lines that are opened up give access to the Black King.
moves.7. O-O: White moves his King to safety.
moves.7... d3:
Black just wastes time here because White is not really interested in wasting a
  move to recapture the pawn.
moves.8. Qb3:
White wastes no time at all!  He goes straight on the attack, creating a 
   battery on the a2-g8 diagonal and threatning 9.Bxf7 , which will win a pawn
   and check the Black King.
moves.8... Qf6: Black defends the pawn on f7 but he places his Queen on a vulnerable square.
moves.9. e5:
setting up the trap of  9. Nxe5 which leads to 10.Re1 d6  11. Nxe5 dxe5 
  12. Qa4  and then 13.Qxa5 winning the Black bishop.
moves.9... Qg6:
Black is correct to know that when your King is still in the center you should 
  avoid opening up any new files.
moves.10. Re1: Putting the Rook on the same file as Black's King.
moves.10... Nge7:
Development is crucial and Black clears the way so that he can consider
   o-o
moves.11. Ba3: Placing the bishop on a very powerful diagonal that leads towards Black's King.
moves.11... b5:
Instead of getting his king to safety by 11.0-0, Black tries to counter-attack. 
   He has forgotten about the principle that you should not open lines when 
   your King is still in the center.
moves.13... Bb6:
To stop  14.Bxe7  Kxe7 leaving the King unable to castle ( 14. Nxe7 simpily just
  drops the a5 bishop).
moves.14... Bb7: !  Putting the bishop on a powerful diagonal leading towards White's King.
moves.15. Ne4 Qf5:
Black continues to waste even more time and just leaves his King in the center
  where it is exposed to attack.
moves.16. Bxd3:
Capturing the pawn and is also threatning 17. Nd6 , with a discovered attack 
  on Black's Queen.
moves.16... Qh5: Getting of the very dangerous b1-h7 diagonal.
moves.17. Nf6+:
Now as you can all see. White wants to force Black to take the Knight on f6
 ( If Black moves his King here then the White Knight will just take the Black 
  Queen on h5) The point behind White's sacrifice is so after 18. exf6 White has 
 just blasted open the e-file and has gave the White  Rooks an invitation to join 
 the hunt for Black's King. The possibility of opening up some lines against the 
 enemy King should absolutly always be considered.
moves.18. exf6 Rg8: Placing a Rook on the same file as White's King.
moves.19. Rad1: Getting the other Rook ready for the attack.
moves.19... Qxf3:
Black has to really take the Knight here  because now he is threatning 
   20. Qxg2 checkmate.
moves.20... Nxe7:
?   White now has a forced mate. I think that Black overlooked White's stunning
      reply. But a better defence would have been 20. Kd8!  21. Rxd7  Kc8 
      22. Rd8 !  Kxd8 ( not 22. Nxd8 because that leads to 23.Qd7 !! Kxd7 
      24. Bf5   and then followed by 25.Bd7 checkmate)  23. Bf5  Qxd1  
      24. Qxd1  Nd4  25. g3  ( that defends the g2 pawn before taking the Knight
      on d4- The Knight is pinned and will not jump away) 25. Bd5  26. cxd4
      resulting into a won game for White.
moves.21... Kxd7: If 21.Kf8 then Qxe7 or Bxe7 will be checkmate.
moves.22. Bf5+: Black's army will not be able to help because Black is in a double check.
moves.22... Ke8: If the Black King tried  to escape with 22. Kc6 then  23. Bd7 is checkmate.
moves.23. Bd7+ Kf8 24. Bxe7#:
Checkmate. This is the final position. Anderssen must have been quite fond of 
  checkmating his opponents by placing a Bishop on e7!
